content.description: To study learned behavior in mice, researchers used a sample of mice in a maze experiment. Each mouse had to find its way through a maze to reach food at the end. The mouse was timed on its first run through the maze and again on its tenth run through the maze. The difference in the times was recorded for each mouse.
content.question: Which of the following is the most appropriate inference procedure for the researchers to use?

choices.label: A two-sample <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for a difference between proportions
A two-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for a difference between means
A matched-pairs <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for a mean difference
A one-sample <math alttext="z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for a population proportion
A one-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for a sample mean difference

content.answer: A matched-pairs <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for a mean difference

topic.text: 7.2: Constructing a Confidence Interval for a Population Mean

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate inference method for confidence intervals.
